caption_original:
#ConsumerAlert: The Competition Bureau is urging consumers to be wary of deceptive tactics used by door-to-door salespeople trying to get you to sign a contract for a new water heater or heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system.

These salespeople may misrepresent themselves as your current supplier, a local utility or the municipality when, in fact, they work for private companies that are unaffiliated with your current supplier or any government agency. Many use high-pressure tactics to get into your home, saying that an urgent inspection of your water heater or HVAC system is needed and demanding that you sign a contract with them on the spot. Unfortunately, once you enter into a long-term contract, it’s too late, leaving you to pay exorbitant cancellation fees to get out of it.

Get tips on how to avoid getting caught in this situation: http://ow.ly/4Ni9302wdjW

Many use high-pressure tactics to get into your home, saying that an urgent inspection of your water heater or HVAC system is needed and demanding that you sign a contract with them on the spot. Unfortunately, once you enter into a long-term contract, it’s too late, leaving you to pay erbitant cancellation fees to get out of it. Get tips on how to avoid getting caught in this situation:

caption_original:
#ScamAlert: Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and claiming that you owe the government back taxes.

These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA. If you receive a call, ask for the caller’s name, phone number and office location so that you can validate their identity BEFORE you give any personal information. Contact the CRA at 1-800-959-8281 to verify that the caller is legit.

Remember to be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information over the phone or by email. Here are some tips to tell if it’s really the CRA calling you: http://ow.ly/aaOV301UMld
